subject: RE: JUnit 4 restructuring

messageBody:
Thank you for the feedback. My own experience and that of most of the people
who have responded is that @Before and @After read well. I suppose it
depends a little on how many annotations are present. I don't use any other
annotations in my code, but I can see that @BeforeTestMethod might stand out
better if there were many other annotations.

I am reluctant to change the package name to "samples", because the classes
there are not just examples of how you might use @RunWith, but useful bits
of functionality. They just aren't universally useful. Also, this mirrors
the package naming in previous versions of JUnit.

> Subject: Re: JUnit 4 restructuring

> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Kent Beck" <kentb@e...>
> wrote:<br />
> >   * Before -- annotation for methods to be run before
> each test method<br />
> >   * BeforeClass -- annotation for methods to be run
> before all tests in a<br />
> > class<br />
> >   * After -- annotation for methods to be run after
> each test method<br />
> >   * AfterClass -- annotation for methods to be run
> after all tests in a<br />
> > class<br />
> >   * Ignore -- annotation for test methods that are
> temporarily not to be run<br />
> >   * Test -- annotation for methods that are to be run
> as tests<br />
> >   * Assert -- assertion methods, expected to be used
> via static import<br />
> <br />
> I think Before and After don't tell the programmer enough about the
> context. As you wrote, Before is an 'annotation for methods to be run
> before each test method', so I would call it BeforeTestMethod. It's
> longer but much clearer. When I read my first JUnit 4 Test, 'Before'
> made me think 'before what?'. I was quite(although not entirely) sure
> that it had got to do with the tests but I had no idea if it meant run
> once for a class, once for every test method or just once for all
> tests. I had to look it up to be sure. <br />
> <br />
> For this reason I think that all annotations above should at least
> contain the word 'Test'. <br />
> <br />
> Regarding runner.extensions, I agree with Stephen (if the package is
> actually meant for examples exclusively). <br />
> <br />
> <br />
